newsitem.title: DUBAI: Saudi's National Commercial Bank adding investors.
newsitem.headline: Saudi's National Commercial Bank adding investors.

text.p: Saudi Arabia's National Commercial Bank (NCB) is widening its ownership to 20 Saudi investors, a bank official said on Tuesday.

He said a Saudi cabinet decision on Monday to change the status of the kingdom's biggest privately-owned bank from a joint liability company to a Saudi joint stock company was "a positive development".
"This means that the investors will be widened from a few owners to 20," the official told Reuters. "It is an important development for the bank."
He said that under the change, the investors, all Saudis, would not be allowed to sell their stakes to outsiders for at least two years.
"They can only sell stakes to each other for at least two years," he said.
It was not clear when NCB would offer share ownership to the new investors.
Saudi billionaire Sheikh Khalid bin Mahfouz last July finalised a deal to take over NCB, previously controlled by his family. He and his wife, Naila Abdul-Aziz Kaaki, own the bank.
Mahfouz was made general manager and chairman.
